description:
Chitinimonas lacunae is a species of bacteria that was isolated from a freshwater lake. It belongs to the Proteobacteria phylum, specifically the Betaproteobacteria class.

The cells of Chitinimonas lacunae are gram-negative, rod-shaped, and motile. They are capable of aerobic respiration and can utilize chitin, a complex carbohydrate, as a carbon and energy source.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Chitinimonas lacunae is closely related to other members of the Chitinimonas genus, which are known to play a role in the degradation of chitin in aquatic environments.

The species was first isolated and described in 2011 from a water sample collected from a freshwater lake. Further studies on its physiology, ecology, and potential roles in nutrient cycling within aquatic ecosystems are ongoing.
